channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bird Strike Shatters Malaysia Jet’s Windshields
item.description: As efforts to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 continued, a plane landing in Nepal collided with a flock of ducks.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Countries Divided on Future of Ancient Buddhas
item.description: Thirteen years after the Bamian Buddhas were blasted into rubble, opinion is split on whether to leave them as is, rebuild them, or make copies of them.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy walked his donkeys past a niche where a Buddha once stood in Bamian, Afghanistan.

item.title: No Bail for Former I.R.A. Member Charged in ’72 Killing
item.description: Ivor Bell, 77, is accused in the abduction and murder of Jean McConville, a mother of 10 who had been accused of spying for the British Army.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: U.S. Emerges as Central Stage in Asian Rivalry
item.description: Experts say that each side has the same goal: cajoling Washington into pressuring the other to make concessions in their bitter rivalry over history and geography.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Korean-American groups persuaded the city of Glendale, Calif., near Los Angeles, to build a bronze statue of a “comfort woman.”

item.title: Communist Party Chief Held in Philippines
item.description: The arrests dealt the biggest blow in years to the decades-old rebel group.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Complexity of Conflict Leaves Donors Wary of Aiding Syrians
item.description: The frustration of international aid workers is growing as donations to groups helping Syrians has remained paltry during three years of turmoil.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Donations to groups helping Syrians have remained low. Here, men in Syria prayed beside parcels to be distributed by a United Nations relief group.

item.title: Palestinians Criticize Abbas for Public Fatah Feud at Delicate Time Diplomatically
item.description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, has begun a campaign against his onetime ally, Muhammad Dahlan, a former Fatah security chief, at a delicate time in a diplomatic battle.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, left, in 2003, with Yasir Arafat, center, the father of the Palestinian cause, and Muhammad Dahlan, right.

item.title: Iraqi Journalist Shot Dead by Officer
item.description: Mohammed Bdaiwi, a Radio Free Iraq bureau chief and a professor, was killed by a Kurdish officer in the presidential guard brigade.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Multivehicle Accident in Pakistan Kills More Than 30
item.description: At least 33 people were killed on Saturday in a crash involving two tanker trucks and two buses in southern Pakistan. At least 20 others were injured.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Pro-Russian and Pro-Kiev Camps Dig In Amid Uneasy Calm in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The Kiev revolution and Russia’s aggression have fueled a rift among ordinary Ukrainians and among elites, laying bare the difficulties of establishing political order even if the unsteady peace lasts.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: The burial of Artyom Zhudov, a pro-Russian activist killed in a clash with nationalists in Kharkiv.

item.title: Russian Forces Take Over One of the Last Ukrainian Bases in Crimea
item.description: The assault on Saturday was a larger and more dramatic military operation than at other installations where Ukrainian forces have capitulated steadily in recent days as Russia declared its formal annexation of the region.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, PATRICK REEVELL and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian troops, center, guard Ukrainian soldiers at a military air base in the Crimean town of Belbek.

item.title: Retracing a Lost Flight: A Routine Flight, Till Both Routine and Flight Vanish
item.description: As the search stretches on, authorities look back at the data for clues of the plane’s whereabouts.
item.dc:creator: By PHILIP P. PAN and KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:credit: Rahman Roslan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers on a recent red-eye Malaysia Airlines flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing prepared to board. The flight is one of two that the airline offers on that route daily.

item.title: For Ukraine Military in Crimea, Glum Capitulation and an Uncertain Future
item.description: Forced to leave their bases, Ukrainians must now decide whether to leave Crimea or join the Russian military.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK REEVELL and NOAH SNEIDER

item.title: Times Report on Al Qaeda Is Censored in Pakistan
item.description: A large, blank space replaced the article exploring what the country knew of Osama bin Laden’s final hide-out.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Pope Names Members of Anti-Abuse Group
item.description: The eight names released on Saturday for a special commission suggested that Pope Francis is deliberately shaking up the usual way of doing things at the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN and JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Jet’s Disappearance Puzzles a World Under Constant Electronic Watch
item.description: The continuing uncertainty, with no evidence of what happened to the plane and the people on it, has tormented relatives of those on board and flummoxed aviation experts.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: An Australian search team flew over a boat looking for debris in the Indian Ocean on Saturday.

item.title: N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat
item.description: As the United States made a public case about the dangers of buying from Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, classified documents show that the National Security Agency was creating its own back doors — directly into Huawei’s networks.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Israeli Raid Leaves 3 Dead in West Bank Refugee Area
item.description: Three Palestinians were killed at the Jenin camp when Israeli forces tried to arrest a suspected militant in a raid that threatened to upend the fragile negotiations in the region.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Palestinians carried the body of Hamza Abu El-Hijja, a Hamas operative, who was the target of a raid by Israeli troops.

item.title: In Beijing Talk, Michelle Obama Extols Free Speech
item.description: The first lady told an audience of mainly students that unfettered expression, particularly on the Internet and in the news media, form the basis for a strong, prosperous society.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: “Time and again, we have seen that countries are stronger and more prosperous when the voices and opinions of all their citizens can be heard.”

item.title: Chinese Satellite Spots Object in Search Area for Missing Jetliner
item.description: The object, which Chinese ships are being sent to investigate, is in the area of one of two possible routes investigators think the plane took.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: China's State Administration of Science, Technology and Industry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The object spotted in the Indian Ocean on Saturday is said to be about 74 feet long and 43 feet wide.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: As Numbers Swell, Students Pledge to Continue Occupying Taiwan’s Legislature
item.description: Demonstrators angered by moves to push a trade bill with China through Taiwan’s Legislature have called for talks with the government.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: In Turkey, Twitter Roars After Effort to Block It
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s ban drew international outrage and was defied by thousands of Turks, including President Abdullah Gul, who protested — using Twitter.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Two Turkish women in a cafe in Istanbul hoped to connect to Twitter on Friday after the prime minister tried to shut it down.

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: Rockets Fired in a Test Land in the Sea
item.description: North Korea test-fired 30 short-range rockets off its east coast on Saturday, the latest in a series of military actions condemned by South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: As Sanctions Start, Russia Feels a Sting
item.description: With the onset of sanctions, Russia’s stock indexes opened sharply lower and agencies threatened to cut the country’s creditworthiness, but President Vladimir V. Putin’s oligarchs stood by him.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian soldiers digging a trench at a Ukrainian military base in Crimea. Russia made its annexation of Crimea official Friday.

item.title: Russia’s Shifting of Border Force Stirs U.S. Worry
item.description: The national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, expressed skepticism that troop movements on the border of southern and eastern Ukraine were merely training exercises.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, with her deputy, Benjamin J. Rhodes, at a White House briefing on Friday.
